results.title: In partnership with the people
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Battery Point is one of the oldest parts of Hobart and the City Council is about to put into practice a development plan which will retain the character and charm of this area. Shows the signal station, the seamen’s cottages, the fine houses of the wealthy, Kelly’s Steps, St George’s Church and other historic items.

results.title: The Story of Holmesglen Concrete Housing Project
results.creator_credit: Housing Commission of Victoria and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: The Housing Commission of Victoria has a huge project at Holmesglen, a suburb of Melbourne, for the manufacture of prefabricated houses. All components of a modern house or a block of flats are constructed at this factory and transported in bulk to the place of erection. Concrete walls, chimneys, fences, tiles for roofs, plumbing units, wooden door cupboards and other fittings are all shown under construction and are then shown being fitted into place as the house is erected. Credit is given to the research work being carried out by the CSIRO Building Research Division, particularly in regard to a new type of light weight concrete which has been developed there.

results.title: The Gunpowder Man
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Eastern Suburb's Children's Film Group
results.brief_description:
In this short film, made in 1966, two children build a Guy Fawkes statue, but are spotted by a third child who reveals their secret to their classmates. The children fight over the statue and eventually join forces to light the bonfire together.

The burning of a Guy Fawkes effigy is a tradition that emerged in the UK, initially to commemorate the failure of a plot, known as the Gunpowder Plot, to assassinate King James I in London on 5 November 1605. In its modern form, the tradition is celebrated as more of a social gathering, with a display of bonfires and fireworks. In Australia, it has become less common since the 1970s.

This short film was sponsored by the Eastern Suburbs Children’s Film Group, Melbourne, and produced and directed by John Richardson. Written by John Richardson and Val Fairweather. Featured cast include Christopher Wilson, Scott McClung, Christopher Ely, Robert Bartnik, Ian Mathieson, Daniel Meltzer, Stephen Palamountain and Jamie Steuart.

results.title: Echoes in Freestone
results.creator_credit: Ray Barnes, John M. Bale and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Using sounds from the past, over pictures of the present, the film glimpses a man’s life in pioneering days. Set in the historic town of Richmond, Tasmania, the film shows some of the classic colonial Georgian houses and churches, many of which date from the early days.

results.title: The Bedspread
results.creator_credit: Natalie Green, Elizabeth O'Neill and Berry St Film Productions
results.brief_description: Concerns two poverty-stricken women, Mrs Clancy and Mrs Parsons, living in Melbourne during the depression. Mrs Clancy owns a good bedspread, her pride and joy. Mrs Parsons asks to borrow the bedspread in preparation for a visit by a specialist to her sick daughter. This small incident becomes the focal point of the day. Cast includes Janet Robertson, Moira Claux and Kim Deacon. Based on a short story by Iris Simmons.

results.title: Swarm
results.brief_description:
Sound and image projection specifically commissioned for Eyes Lies and Illusions in 2006.

Multi-site work using projection and audio to create the illusion that a swarm of insects live in the gallery ceiling.

results.title: Possums of Bonegilla
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Agnes Karlik
results.brief_description: Agnes talks of her migrant experience including her time spent at Bonegilla. She especially focuses on friendships made during those early years of alienation and loneliness.

results.title: Type 2014K Image Orthicon camera
results.creator_credit: Films & Equipment Ltd., Vinten and PYE Ltd.
results.brief_description: Pye cameras were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.

constellations_primary.name: News on location
constellations_primary.description: The Pye Orthicon is an example of the type of television cameras used from the 1950s in Australia for both studio and outside broadcast work. Such cameras did not have have the capacity to record while out on location and so outside crews would transmit vision and sound back to studios for recording or live broadcast.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Films & Equipment Ltd., Vinten and PYE Ltd.
results.description:
In 1948, Australian audiences were introduced to television at the Sydney Royal Easter Show. The British electronics company Pye had brought its 405-line cameras and monitors to encourage interest in the new medium.

While it would be eight years until Bruce Gyngell famously welcomed Australia to television, the Pye company was still essential to the burgeoning industry.

Pye cameras like this were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.
description_for_label:
In 1948, Australian audiences were introduced to television at the Sydney Royal Easter Show. The British electronics company Pye had brought its 405-line cameras and monitors to encourage interest in the new medium.

While it would be eight years until Bruce Gyngell famously welcomed Australia to television, the Pye company was still essential to the burgeoning industry.

Pye cameras like this were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.
